content: What's the difference between data.polynomial.induction and data.polynomial.inductions? @Damiano Testa @Anne Baanen @Chris Hughes

Ah, weirdly enough, I had not noticed the presence of the file data.polynomial.induction. After a quick glance, I am tempted to merge the induction and inductions files into a single one and probably move the stuff that is currently in induction and after the induction_on and induction_on' to an already existing file TBD.

Before thinking about this, I will wait for further comments!

Great! I recently used a polynomial induction to prove something, saw your PR and thought about whether your induction would make it easier for me or not. That's why I was familiar with the other file.
I hadn't realized there was another polynomial induction, other than docs#polynomial.rec_on_horner
Ah, but induction is imported by degree.definitions, which is imported by inductions...

Ok, this requires more thought.

I still think that it is probably worthwhile to try to prove variuos forms of "polynomial inductions" at once and to collect them all in single file...
Although I can't actually find something in induction that is used by degree.definitions
Did you call me? Yaël kills-imports Dillies?
I'm not sure that I will have time over the week-end, but I'll look into this next week.
I couldn't simplify the imports. data.polynomial.degree.definitions uses sum_monomial_eq from data.polynomial.induction.
To scare those modules a bit, I still killed some imports around, but nothing fancy.
